org.pojava.datetime
Class Tm

java.lang.Object
  org.pojava.datetime.Tm

public class Tm
extends java.lang.Object

This class converts a DateTime into year, month, day, hour, minute, second, millisecond, nanosecond. It is similar to the tm struct in C.

Author:
John Pile

calcWeekday

public static int calcWeekday(long millis,
                              java.util.TimeZone timeZone)
Return numeric day of week, usually Sun=1, Mon=2, ... , Sat=7;

Parameters:
millis -
timeZone -
Returns:
Numeric day of week, usually Sun=1, Mon=2, ... , Sat=7. See DateTimeConfig.

getYear

public int getYear()
Returns:
Year as YYYY

getMonth

public int getMonth()
Returns month between 1 and 12. Differs from C version of tm, but you can always subtract 1 if you want zero-based.

Returns:
Month as Jan=1, Feb=2, ..., Dec=12

getDay

public int getDay()
Returns day of month between 1 and 31.

Returns:
Day of month.

getHour

public int getHour()
Returns hour of day between 0 and 23.

Returns:
Hour of day.

getMinute

public int getMinute()
Returns minute of hour between 0 and 59.

Returns:
Minute of hour.

getSecond

public int getSecond()
Returns second of minute between 0 and 59.

Returns:
Second of minute.

getMillisecond

public int getMillisecond()
Returns millisecond fraction of second between 0 and 999999.

Returns:
Millisecond fraction of second.

getNanosecond

public int getNanosecond()
Returns nanosecond fraction of second between 0 and 999999999.

Returns:
Nanosecond fraction of second.

getWeekday

public int getWeekday()
Returns weekday between 1 and 7

Returns:
Typically (although configurable) Sun=1 .. Sat=7
